pullRequest.body:
These lemmas were useful for manipulating nested sums while working on the Selberg sieve. They can be used to push a condition from the outer sum into an inner sum. 

---

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

nodes.body: üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by Ruben-VandeVelde.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12866707443/job/35869837525)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12866707443/job/35869837899)

Thanks for the PR!

Aren't those two lemmas special cases of `apply_ite` and `ite_apply`? Could we try not adding any more special cases and instead write a dedicated pair of tactics `push_ifs`/`norm_ifs` to push `ite`/`dite` in/outwards of any expression?

Thanks for the PR!

Aren't those two lemmas special cases of `apply_ite` and `ite_apply`? Could we try not adding any more special cases and instead write a dedicated pair of tactics `push_ifs`/`norm_ifs` to push `ite`/`dite` in/outwards of any expression?

```suggestion
    (if p then (‚àè x ‚àà s, f x) else ‚àè x ‚àà s, g x) = ‚àè x ‚àà s, if p then f x else g x := by
```
no?

Thanks for the review! I've removed the use of the product notation.

What you've written is `prod_ite_irrel`, proved above.

These are supposed to be `simp_rw` lemmas to be used for nested sums. The pattern `if p then f x else 0` comes up naturally from [Finset.sum_filter](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/BigOperators/Group/Finset/Basic.html#Finset.sum_filter), and doesn't match against `prod_ite_irrel`

[As an example](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20008/files#diff-0c922162d6078c849fff74f8322f93ac418fbfb2a413cfbe1204e744472df019R210) here's an expression where I want to push the condition `k ^ 2 ‚â§ y` inwards so that I can swap the two sums:
`‚àë k ‚àà divisors P, if k ^ 2 ‚â§ y then (‚àë d ‚àà divisors P, if d ‚à£ k ‚àß l ‚à£ d then (Œº d:‚Ñù) else 0) * g k * S‚Åª¬π else 0`

I agree we probably want a `push`/`norm` tactic, but this lemma is really for manipulating sums, not `ite` statements.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(BigOperators): ite_prod_one / ite_sum_zero
